text: Map of the fortifications of the Grand Harbour and Marsamxett in 1803. This is a list of fortifications of Malta. ==Prehistoric fortifications== {|class="wikitable sortable" |- ! scope="col"| Name ! class="unsortable" scope="col" | Image ! scope="col" | Location ! class="unsortable" scope="col" | Built ! scope="col" class="unsortable" style ="width:25%" | Status |- ! scope="row" | | style="text-align:center;"| 150px | | Bronze Age | Scant remains |- ! scope="row" | | style="text-align:center;"| 150px | | c.1450 BC | One bastion intact |- ! scope="row" | | style="text-align:center;"| 150px | | Bronze Age | Scant remains |- ! scope="row" | | style="text-align:center;"| | | Bronze Age | Scant remains |- ! scope="row" | | style="text-align:center;"| | | Bronze Age | Scant remains |- ! scope="row" | | style="text- align:center;"| | | Bronze Age | Scant remains |} ==Walled cities== {|class="wikitable sortable" |- ! scope="col"| Name ! class="unsortable" scope="col" | Image ! scope="col" | Location ! class="unsortable" scope="col" | Built ! scope="col" class="unsortable" | Builder ! scope="col" class="unsortable" style ="width:25%" | Status |- ! scope="row" | | style="text-align:center;"| 150px | | c.13th–18th centuries | Order of Saint John | Mostly intact, undergoing restoration |- ! scope="row" | | style="text- align:center;"| 150px | | Antiquity–1622 | Crown of Aragon Order of Saint John | Intact. According to Ramon Muntaner (1283) a prominent Aragonite tower existed on the site in the whereabouts of the arch/remains of a Siculo-Norman style villa. A number of outer towers were places outside the Citadel.https://www.um.edu.mt/library/oar/bitstream/123456789/15356/1/Barumbari%20Giren%20and%20Mgiebah%20-%20Vernacular%20gems%20in%20oblivion.pdf |- ! The ones listed here are those of which some remains survive, or which are definitely known to have existed. ==Lines of fortification== {|class="wikitable sortable" |- ! scope="col"| Name ! class="unsortable" scope="col" | Image ! scope="col" | Location ! scope="col" | Built ! scope="col" class="unsortable" | Builder ! scope="col" class="unsortable" style ="width:25%" | Status |- ! scope="row" | | style="text-align:center;"| 150px | | 1871–1880 | United Kingdom | Mostly intact |- ! scope="row" | | style="text-align:center;"| 150px | | 1875–1899 | United Kingdom | Partially intact |} Notes: *The Floriana Lines, Santa Margherita Lines and the Cottonera Lines are also lines of fortification, but they are listed with the walled cities since they are close to settlements. ==Stop walls== *The 'stop wall' that plugged a fortification gap in Wied Żnuber ==Fortified houses and privately built towers== *Ta' Cirpisin Tower *Castellan Country House {|class="wikitable sortable" |- ! scope="col"| Name ! class="unsortable" scope="col" | Image ! scope="col" | Location ! scope="col" | Built ! scope="col" | Builder ! scope="col" class="unsortable" style ="width:25%" | Status |- ! scope="row" | | style="text-align:center;"| | | 1702 or 1775 | | Destroyed during WWII |- ! scope="row" | | style="text- align:center;"| 150px | | | | Intact |- ! scope="row" | | style="text- align:center;"| 150px | | | | Intact |- ! scope="row" | | style="text- align:center;"| 150px | | | | Intact. Built before 1649. Also known as tas- Sarretta Tower. Intact but machicolations removed. They appear to were still partially intact on 21 August, 1933. |- ! scope="row" | | style="text- align:center;"| 150px | | | | Intact |- ! scope="row" | | style="text- align:center;"| 150px | | | | Intact |- ! scope="row" | | style="text- align:center;"| | | | | Demolished, some stonework survives |- ! scope="row" | | style="text-align:center;"| 150px | | | | Dismantled; stonework used to built farmhouses |- ! scope="row" | | style="text-align:center;"| 150px | | | | Intact, restored |- ! scope="row" | | style="text-align:center;"| | | | | Intact, converted into a farmhouse |- ! scope="row" | | | | | | Destroyed during WWII |- ! scope="row" | | style="text-align:center;"| 150px | | | | Intact |- ! scope="row" | | style="text-align:center;"| 150px | | | D'Aurel Family | Intact |- ! scope="row" | | style="text-align:center;"| 150px | | | | Intact and used as a rural building with a close by watermill. |- ! scope="row" | | style="text-align:center;"| 150px | | | | Intact |- ! scope="row" | | style="text-align:center;"| 150px | | | | Intact.
